PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: WTI crude futures rose 2.4%
content:
AUSTRALIA

Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA AT)
- CBA knowingly opened transaction accounts for customers it had reasons to suspect of money laundering according to AUSTRAC. (AFR)
- Some of the world's largest pension funds are said to be planning a class action suit against CBA. (The Australian)

Select Harvests (SHV AT)
- Co. is said to be mulling a bid for Maxwell Foods. (AFR)

Telstra (TLS AT)
- Co. CEO stated that NBN would need to lower wholesale prices for retail telecom firms to make money. (The Australian)

Westgold Resources (WGX AT)
- Co. revises gold production guidance for 2018 to 275K ounces from around 300K ounces due to reduced productivity at Higginsville operations. (Newswires)

Energy
- WTI crude futures rose 2.4% to above USD 63/bbl. (Newswires)

Other News
- Australian PM Turnbull is said to have signed off on all the key budget measures including personal income tax cuts, a month prior to its release. (The Australian)

Data Recap
- Australian Foreign Reserves (AUD)(Mar) 76.6B (Prev. 70.8B). (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Eisai (4523 JT)
- Co. unit Morphotek agrees to licence proprietary Eribulin-Linker Payload to Bliss Biopharmaceutical. (Newswires)  

Toyo Seikan (5901 JT)
- Co. said to guide FY oper. profit to increase 13% Y/Y to JPY 34bln. (Newswires)

Yaskawa (6506 JT)
- Co. plans to spend JPY 10bln on construction of R&D centre. (Newswires)

Power Related
- Japan is seeking to ease regulations to encourage domestic power companies to invest in overseas power plant projects and boost the country's infrastructure exports to Southeast Asia. (Nikkei)

Other News
- BoJ Governor Kuroda reiterated will continue with powerful easing to achieve target and that inflation is still a distant from the target, while he also said he told PM Abe the BoJ will do the utmost to reach the 2% target as quick as possible. Furthermore, BoJ Governor Kuroda said he is confident the BoJ can smoothly engineer exit from easy policy but added the economy is yet to reach timing for BoJ to reveal exit strategy, while he also noted that central banks must be aware about the impact of prolonged easing via conventional or non-conventional monetary policy. (Newswires)
- Japanese GDP fell 1.5% M/M during February amid reduced exports, according to the JCER. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

SK Telecom (017670 KS)
- Some of Co. subscribers are requesting a higher amount of compensation than the Co. offered for service outage. (Newswires)

STX Offshore & Shipbuilding (067250 KS)
- Co. is reportedly anticipated to file for court receivership, although there were also reports that it had reached an agreement with its union to lower labour costs which could keep the troubled firm afloat. (Newswires/Yonhap)

GM Korea
- Co. is reportedly to pay its assembly line workers this month, while there were also reports it is to reduce output by 130K vehicles next year. (Newswires)

Other News
- US and North Korea are said to want different paths to denuclearization in which Washington is said to prefer a model of disarming before lifting sanctions, while Pyongyang is hoping for a phaseout. (Nikkei)
- Press reports note increasing concern regarding the negative effect from strengthening KRW on the nation’s exports. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China have reportedly drafted detailed counter-measures on US trade moves, while there were earlier unconfirmed source reports that China are looking at CNY devaluation as a tool in their trade spat with the US. (Newswires)

China’s Foreign Ministry said protectionism is not a solution and the wrong measures of the US have raised concerns of the international community. The Foreign Ministry added that there have been no negotiations with the US and that the US is to blame for the trade friction (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda reiterated will continue with powerful easing to achieve target and that inflation is still a distant from the target, while he also said he told PM Abe the BoJ will do the utmost to reach the 2% target as quick as possible. Furthermore, BoJ Governor Kuroda said he is confident the BoJ can smoothly engineer exit from easy policy but added the economy is yet to reach timing for BoJ to reveal exit strategy, while he also noted that central banks must be aware about the impact of prolonged easing via conventional or non-conventional monetary policy. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

ECB’s Coeure (neutral) noted the ECB is to discuss timing of QE soon and also commented that growth outlook is not a warrant to modify current monetary policy stance. (Newswires)

ECB’s Praet (dove) said data suggests there is no need to change the ECB's outlook, while he also stated ample degree of monetary stimulus remains necessary and that inflation remains subdued. (Newswires)

EU exploring counter-measures to US aluminium tariffs, according to trade body European Aluminium. (Newswires)


FX

DXY was lower against most majors on Monday, falling beneath the 90.000 figure. Weakness was exacerbated slightly in late trade after the CBO raised deficit forecasts, but the focus overall remained on the wider geopolitical/trade wars narrative. Attention is on overnight comments from China’s President Xi, to see whether there is any follow through on China’s tough retaliatory talk. USD focussed traders are also mindful of the FOMC meeting minutes and CPI data, both on the slate for Wednesday.

EUR price action was mainly dictated by the USD side of the pair, with EURUSD continuing to strengthen slightly in wake of the NFP report on Friday. The 1.23 level is proving sticky, and the pair finds itself consolidating just above the level heading into APAC (1.2310-1.2330).

JPY was ignoring US yields (higher) as well as the positive sentiment among equity traders (equities up). USDJPY traded in the middle of its recent range (recent range: 106.30 to 107.80; today’s range 106.75 to 107.20), though the bias seems towards the down-side in late US trading.

GBP was consolidating around 1.41 against the greenback, before a bout of USD weakness helped with a push towards 1.4160. Wednesday’s data dump is in vogue, as well as a host of BOE policymakers due to speak in the week. Analysts cite short-term resistance under 1.40 (50dma) and the March high (mid 1.42s) are resistance on the top-side.

CAD traded higher, with USDCAD falling to 1.27 after the BOC’s business outlook survey, which hints at price pressures ahead, though the survey did suggest that GDP growth will slow to below potential this year, which may have caused BOC officials to shift uncomfortably in their seats. The BOC is not expected to adjust rates at its April meeting next week; markets are not fully pricing in a hike until September, while there is only a 20% chance of a hike next week.

AUD shrugged-off early concerns about trade wars/geopolitics to move higher as USD was sold near the cash open. The tone of US policymakers seems to be framing trade wars as a negotiating tactic. NZD action was similar.


COMMODITIES

There wasn’t a lot of news directly driving crude prices on Monday, with oil takings its cue from the general risk tone, and equities (both firm). Geopolitical concerns are dominating the thoughts of traders; the Iranian President today warned that US President Trump would regret pulling out of the nuclear deal, promising a strong response if the US re-applied sanctions on Iran. There are also whispers of potential military action in the Middle East after US policymakers refused to rule out the option when asked about Syria; Trump said a US response would come within 48 hours. Elsewhere, one potential source of support was removed after Norway’s labour union called off strike action after agreeing a new wage deal. In terms of inventories, analysts expect crude stocks to build by 200k barrels in the week, Cushing is seen building by 1.5mln, distillates are expected to draw 400k barrels, and gasoline is seen drawing by 1.4mln barrels. Front WTI futures settled $1.36 higher at $63.42/bbl; front Brent settled $1.54 higher at $68.65/bbl.
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump condemned the reported chemical attack in Syria and stated that the US is to make decision on next step in 24-48 hours, while Trump also suggested a decision may come by the end of today and did not rule out military action. (Newswires)

US envoy to the UN Nikki Haley stated the US ‘will respond’ to Syria’s chemical attack irrespective of the UN security council intervention. However, there were also comments from the Russian UN envoy that the US has been warned by Moscow that military action in Syria could lead to "grave repercussions". (Newswires)


US

US President Trump lawyer Cohen was raided by the FBI under referral from Special Counsel Mueller in which the FBI seized documents relating to tax and businesses records, as well as info regarding payments to Stormy Daniels. However, reports later stated that it was unclear if the FBI raid on Trump lawyer Michael Cohen's office is related or not to Mueller investigation or Stormy Daniels, according to a source. (Newswires/CBS)

US President Trump said that we are 'fairly close' on NAFTA, while he also commented that if China hits US farmers, then the US will make it up to the farmers. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow is said to be optimistic about trade talks, although does not know if US will impose China tariffs or not, while he also commented that progress is being made in renegotiating NAFTA. (Newswires)

White House Chief of Staff Kelly could leave by the summer. (Fox Business)


MARKET RECAP

US equity futures rebounded over the weekend from Friday trade following efforts from the US to alleviate trade concerns; US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated the US is willing to negotiate, but Trump is prepared to defend US interests. Healthcare and Technology led today’s US cash market, with Merck (MRK) leading the DJ closing over 5% higher as its phase 3 Keynote trial met its primary endpoint of overall survival. In M&A news sources reported Viacom (VIAB) asked CBS (CBS) to raise its merger offer by $2.8bln, with CBS still waiting to respond, however, an unnamed CBS investor has asked the company to not pay above market price for Viacom. Elsewhere, WSJ citing sources said US DoJ is to approve Bayer’s (BAYN GY) acquisition of Monsanto (MON) after the two make concessions. SPX +0.34% at 2613, NDX +0.61% at 6472, DJI +0.2% at 23980.

Although Treasury yields rose modestly on Monday, curve spreads were narrower by between 1bps and 2bps at settlement. While there were lingering concerns about trade wars/geopolitics, volumes and yields were within Friday’s range. Losses were trimmed in the US afternoon, following the CBO budget and economic outlook report, which forecast higher deficits on the back of GOP spending plans. The US Treasury will sell $64bln in 3s/10s/30s this week; with $76.5bln maturing at mid-month, the Treasury will be paying down some $12.5bln. US 10-Year T-Note Futures settle 3+ ticks lower at 120-29.

US MARKET WRAP: Stocks up despite trade wars/geopolitics
content:
*SNAPSHOT: Stocks up, USD lower, treasuries lower, oil higher
*REAR-VIEW: Syria chemical attack, Russian sanctions, BoC Survey & ECB speak
*AHEAD: President Xi Jinping to speak, Fed/ECB/BoE speak (Tues)

* TRADE WARS: China President Xi Jinping will deliver comments to the Boao Conference overnight (the Asian version of Davos), and attention will be on comments relating to trade wars. China is said to be considering a gradual devaluation of the yuan, which put upward pressure on USDCNH; other unconfirmed sources have suggested that China has already halted US Treasury purchases, which would be seen as a strong escalation of trade wars. There seems to be a consensus growing around the idea that the US’ tough stance is a negotiating tactic design to bring Chinese concessions. US NEC Director Kudlow expressed optimism around trade talks today and said he was unsure whether the US will impose China tariffs or not. (Over the weekend, WSJ reported that the USTR was already exchanging letters with Chinese economic envoys on measures that China could take to avert a trade war).

* NAFTA: Despite reports suggesting that no deal ‘in principle’ is likely to be announced at the Summit of Americas this week, there were further constructive comments from US officials on the progress of NAFTA talks; Trump said partners are ‘fairly close’ to a deal, while NEC Director Kudlow also noted progress was being made. The Mexicans, meanwhile, said there were no conditions to reach a NAFTA deal this week, adding that there was an 80% chance that NAFTA parties could reach an agreement in principle by the first week of May.

* GEOPOLITICS: Last week’s US sanctions hit Russian assets on Monday. Following on from weekend tough talk, on Monday, US President Trump suggested that Russia may have been responsible in the Syrian chemical weapons attack – which has been described by humanitarian organisations as a war crime – and the US was considering what action to take, with a decision due within 48 hours; military action has not been ruled out.

* ECB: At the release of the central bank’s 2017 annual report, ECB president Draghi said he is confident that inflation will move higher, but is uncertain about the degree of economic slack that remains. Draghi added that the recent stock market slide has not had an impact on broader financial conditions. ECB VP Constancio largely repeated previous comments that deflationary risks have vanished, though inflation has not responded as the ECB has desired. The central bank’s chief economist Praet emphasised data dependence, arguing that an ample degree of stimulus was still required, noting that inflation remains subdued and that there was no reason to change the ECB’s outlook. ECB’s Coeure, meanwhile, said the growth outlook does not warrant any modifications to the ECB’s current policy stance, elsewhere adding that the timing of QE exit will be discussed soon.

subject: UBS Weekly FX Flows: Strong CHF inflows
content:
• CHF was the most bought in G10 and recorded inflows for a fifth week in a row, during a week with mixed risk sentiment and higher-than-expected Swiss inflation in March.
  • GBP was also bid despite soft services PMI on Thursday, as NZD saw inflows.
  • USD was marginally bought as strong inflows in the middle of the week were partially offset by heavy selling on Friday, corresponding to soft US labour data and Fed Chair Powell's speech.
  • SEK was the most sold, registering outflows for the first time in six weeks.
  • EUR also saw strong selling interest with the majority of outflows on Tuesday and Wednesday.
  • AUD saw outflows despite retail sales data beating market expectations on Tuesday as CAD experienced selling interest in the latter half of the week even as labour data was somewhat stronger than expected.
  • NOK and JPY were both sold for the first time in three weeks.

subject: PRIMER: CBO Budget and Economic Outlook will be published at 1900 BST/1400 EDT
content:
The CBO is expected to revise up its US deficit forecasts. Previously, the CBO estimate the FY 2018 deficit at USD 563bln, and the FY 2019 deficit at USD 689bln.

Some suggest that the CBO expectations are likely to be lower than the actual deficit numbers that transpire: "That means the deficit projections will be based on the presumption that the tax cuts enacted last year that currently phase out will in fact end," says Stan Collender, a former CBO insider. "That means the CBO forecast will assume that future revenues will be higher and the deficit lower compared to what is likely to occur."

Deficits are expected to tick higher in the months ahead, and the US Treasury is said to be attempting to compensate for rising deficits through increased debt issuance, which will likely to place upward pressure on bond yields, analysts say.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar back under pressure as US trades words with China and Russia
content:
DXY

A real game of two halves for the Greenback with gains made early on Monday’s session amidst reports that China may resort to weakening the CNY as part of its next counter moves against the US’ latest proposed import tariffs. However, the move was relatively brief and the index is back below the psychological 90.000 level despite the Usd maintaining its outperformance vs EM currencies and the Rub especially (up through 60.000 and a key tech level to 60.545 at one stage), though the Try also weakened further to circa 4.0750 and fresh all time lows.

JPY

Unable to recover sub-107.00 levels vs the Usd convincingly, but the headline pair off 107.20 highs amidst ongoing pledges from the BoJ and Japanese Government to use all policy tools to hit the 2% inflation target. Note also, some option expiry interest (850 mn) at the figure may have exerted influence.

GBP/NZD/EUR

Vying for best G10 performer vs the Usd, the former still benefiting from April’s apparent supportive seasonality as Cable climbed above 1.4160 and Eur/Gbp tested the water under 0.8700 before the single currency cleared some key chart levels vs the Usd on the way to just shy of 1.2330 (200 HMA at 1.2295 and a fib at 1.2314). Nzd/Usd stayed close to 0.7300 and Nzd/Aud 1.0500 ahead of NZIER confidence later tonight and with the AUD still undermined by US-Chinese trade war contagion implications.

CAD   

Choppy either side of 1.2800 vs its US peer but ending the session just below 1.2750 amidst more positive NAFTA talk from Canada and Mexico (latter suggesting that while a deal may not be in the offing for the America’s Summit there is an 80% chance of a provisional agreement in the 1st week of May). Loonie now looking at the BoC Business Outlook Survey, which seems relatively upbeat on balance and could see 1.2700 tested next.

subject: BOC Senior Loan Officer Survey -5.2 (Prev. -6.4), Business Outlook Future Sales 16 (Prev. +8)
content:
• Inflation expectations over the next two years have picked up
  • Remaining slack confined to energy producing regions
  • Forward-looking sales indicators remain positive across most regions and sectors. Some firms expect a moderation in sales activity from high levels in the past year or a gradual slowing of the pace of the recovery in the energy sector.
  • While firms’ expectations for US economic growth have strengthened further, some cited rising protectionism and reduced competitiveness as factors limiting the impact on their sales.
  • Although less so than in recent surveys, intentions to increase investment continue to be widespread. Employment intentions are solidly positive, based on firms’ plans for hiring to support expected sales growth or to expand operations.
  • Indicators of capacity pressures and labour shortages edged down but are still close to recent high levels. Remaining economic slack appears to be mostly concentrated in the energy-producing regions.
  • Despite expectations for faster input price growth overall, on balance, firms continue to anticipate only modest acceleration in the growth of their output prices due to competitive pressures. Partly driven by rising labour costs, inflation expectations picked up but are still well within the Bank’s inflation-control range of 1 to 3 per cent.
  • While credit conditions were unchanged for most firms, the indicator points to a slight tightening.
  • The Business Outlook Survey indicator continues to be high, signalling positive business sentiment.
  • Click here for full release

subject: Preview: BoC Business Survey due at 15.30BST/10.30ET
content: Ahead of the Bank of Canada's next rate decision on 18th April, the BoC releases its latest Business Survey. The chance of a rate hike remains small at the meeting according to RBC while BMO also suggests the BoC is likely to hold on from hiking rates until H2 2018. Capacity pressure is building up in the economy as both wage growth and inflation appear solid, although GDP growth remains stable. Scotiabank notes any insights from this survey over investment purposes may be interesting given the recent mixed signals from capital goods imports, which make up most of the country’s imports. As a side note, evidence from the survey were gathered for March thus they will not reflect the uncertainty driven by the latest NAFTA and US-China trade developments.

subject: Goldman Sachs note on Trump tariff threats, says US tariff threats are not this dramatic
content: Goldman believes the direct macroeconomic implications are negative directionally, however they think the announced and threatened tariffs are not this dramatic and their baseline expectation remains a compromise. Goldman do believe the environment is becoming less pleasant; noting growth is slightly weaker, inflation is slightly higher, financial markets volatility has increased and economic imbalances are becoming more visible, especially in government finance.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: 9th April 2018 - Now available in the Research Suite
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities begin the week on the front foot, supported by US efforts to alleviate trade concerns
  • Reports suggesting China is looking at CNY devaluation briefly lifts USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include speeches from ECB’s Praet and Constancio

 

TRADE WARS

US President Trump commented that he will always be friends with Chinese President Xi Jinping no matter what happens regarding the dispute on trade, while President Trump also noted that he predicts the US would prevail and reach agreements with China on trade issues. (Twitter)

China are looking at CNY devaluation as a tool in their trade spat with the US, according to sources. (Newswires)

China’s Foreign Ministry said that there have been no negotiations with the US, and that the US is to blame for the trade friction. (Newswires)

PBoC policy adviser said that China should invest more in real assets rather than invest in US debt and that US is seeking to restrict China's rise via trade war. However, there were also comments from China think-tank CASS that the nation is unlikely to use USTs as a trade war weapon. That said, this appears to be at odds with research from SGH Macro which suggests that their understanding is that China has halted purchases of USTs. (Newswires/SGH Macro)

Reports stated that no deal in principle regarding NAFTA is expected to be announced in the upcoming Summit of Americas in Lima, Peru. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian stocks initially began the week rangebound with a non-committal tone seen in the region following the stock rout last Friday on Wall St after President Trump upped the ante on possible trade tariffs against China and US NFP data fell short of estimates. However, sentiment then gradually improved throughout the trading day which was attributed to US efforts over the weekend to alleviate trade concerns in which President Trump predicted that the US would reach an agreement with China on trade and after White House economic adviser Kudlow explicitly stated that this is not a trade war. As such, ASX 200 (+0.4%) shrugged off the early indecision and traded positive, although weakness in mining and energy names capped upside, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was lifted by JPY weakness. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) recovered from the initial cobwebs seen on the mainland’s re-open from a 4-day closure and first opportunity to react to the additional USD 100bln tariff consideration against China, while Hang Seng (+1.3%) outperformed on declining money market rates after the PBoC resumed liquidity operations after halting for over 2 weeks. Finally, 10-yr JGBs were uneventful with marginal gains seen as they tracked recent price action in T-notes and with the BoJ also in the market to the tune of JPY 710bln in the belly to super-long end.

PBoC injected CNY 10bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3114 (Prev. 6.2926)

BoJ Governor Kuroda says will continue with powerful easing to achieve target. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed’s Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said that the US economy is very strong and that he is optimistic on inflation reaching 2% target. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Italy’s three main right-leaning parties have announced that they will present a united front ahead of a fresh round of talks to form a government this week. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European bourses (Eurostoxx 50 +0.7%) have kicked the week off on the front-foot in fitting with the positivity seen during Asia-Pac hours. Asian bourses were supported by US efforts over the weekend to alleviate trade concerns in which President Trump predicted that the US would reach an agreement with China on trade and after White House economic adviser Kudlow explicitly stated that this is not a trade war. As such, all ten sectors in Europe trade in positive territory with financial names outperforming as Deutsche Bank (+4.0%) leads the sector after news they have appointed Christian Sewing as CEO; Commerzbank (+1.5%) are also seen higher in sympathy. Elsewhere, energy names modestly lag their peers given price action in the energy sector. In terms of other individual movers in what’s been a busy morning of equity newsflow, EDP (+3.8%) have been supported by reports of a potential bid by Engie (-0.5%), Rolls Royce (+1.9%) are seen higher after offloading L’Orange to Woodward for EUR 700mln and shares in Casino (+1.8%) have been lifted by a positive broker move at Deutsche Bank.

FX         

In FX markets, for the DXY, a decent comeback from Friday’s post-NFP data lows and some short-lived gains on the back of source reports about China contemplating Yuan devaluation as an option in its ongoing war of words vs the US on trade and import tariffs. The Index briefly probed above 90.200 compared to lows just above 90.000 as USD/CNY spiked to just over 6.3250 after the PBoC’s official 6.3114 mid-point fix. The Kiwi is back on top of the G10 rankings, but again not really on anything fundamental for the currency or NZ-wise and more on cross flows as the AUD continues to underperform and bear the brunt of any negative repercussions from a full-blown US-China-global trade war. NZD/USD is back near 0.7300 and AUD/NZD is re-testing support just ahead of 1.0500 as AUD/USD continues to reject advances towards 0.7700. Another gainer vs the USD and other majors amidst ongoing bullish Sterling seasonal factors, as Cable pivots 1.4100, EUR/GBP straddles 0.8700 (market contacts noting offers at the figure earlier) and GBP/JPY reclaims 151.00, albeit just. Note, significantly firmer than Halifax house prices also underpinned the Pound, fleetingly. CAD/EUR/JPY/CHF are all narrowly mixed vs the Greenback in typically quiet early Monday trade, with USD/CAD still capped ahead of 1.2800 amidst more reports of positive NAFTA talks, though a deal may not be reached in principle in time for the upcoming Summit of Americas as had been touted. EUR/USD is extremely contained between 1.2660-90, USD/JPY has recoiled around the 107.00 axis and USD/CHF is trapped within 0.9590-0.96.

FIXED INCOME

Core bonds are on the retreat again after a rebound on the China devaluation headlines soon fizzled out, with Bunds and Gilts now extending losses to 21 and 26 ticks respectively at the new 159.34 and 122.18 Eurex and Liffe intraday lows. EU stocks are hugging highs on less anxiety over the US-China trade tiff in general, although latest Chinese comments remain relatively resolute and come with the threat of Yuan devaluation, according to sources anyway. US Treasuries also on the retreat after initial post-US labour data gains last Friday and with the curve steeper ahead of this week’s auctions, FOMC minutes and CPI data. Back to the 10 year EU benchmarks, and technically Bund bears may now look at Friday’s low of 159.15, while nearest downside chart support comes in at 122.10, which is the April 5 session base.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures trade modestly higher but in close proximity to some of the lows seen on Friday amid trade concerns and an uptick in the Baker Hughes rig count. Elsewhere, energy-specific newsflow has been relatively quiet over the weekend but traders will continue to be mindful of geopolitical developments with US President Trump warning Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and allies that they could pay a big price following a suspected chemical attack that killed dozens over the weekend. Furthermore, Iranian President Rouhani has stated that US President Trump will regret any withdrawal from the Iranian nuclear deal and that Iran’s response to the matter will be stronger than imagined. In metals markets, spot gold has fallen victim to the apparent return of risk appetite to the market and the modestly firmer USD. Elsewhere, Dalian iron ore slipped to a 10-month low in Asia-Pac trade amid ongoing trade concerns whilst aluminium has been seen higher during London hours amid the potential fallout of sanctions by the US on Russian aluminium producer Rusal.

Elsewhere, energy names modestly lag their peers given price action in the energy sector. In terms of other individual movers in what’s been a busy morning of equity newsflow, EDP (+4.5%) have been supported by reports of a potential bid by Engie (-0.3%), Rolls Royce (+1.6%) are seen higher after offloading L’Orange to Woodward for EUR 700mln and shares in Casino (+2.5%) have been lifted by a positive broker move at Deutsche Bank.

In FX markets, for the DYX, a decent comeback from Friday’s post-NFP data lows and some short-lived gains on the back of source reports about China contemplating Yuan devaluation as an option in its ongoing war of words vs the US on trade and import tariffs. The Index briefly probed above 90.200 compared to lows just above 90.000 as USD/CNY spiked to just over 6.3250 after the PBoC’s official 6.3114 mid-point fix. The Kiwi is back on top of the G10 rankings, but again not really on anything fundamental for the currency or NZ-wise and more on cross flows as the AUD continues to underperform and bear the brunt of any negative repercussions from a full-blown US-China-global trade war. NZD/USD is back near 0.7300 and AUD/NZD is re-testing support just ahead of 1.0500 as AUD/USD continues to reject advances towards 0.7700. Another gainer vs the USD and other majors amidst ongoing bullish Sterling seasonal factors, as Cable pivots 1.4100, EUR/GBP straddles 0.8700 (market contacts noting offers at the figure earlier) and GBP/JPY reclaims 151.00, albeit just. Note, significantly firmer than Halifax house prices also underpinned the Pound, fleetingly. CAD/EUR/JPY/CHF are all narrowly mixed vs the Greenback in typically quiet early Monday trade, with USD/CAD still capped ahead of 1.2800 amidst more reports of positive NAFTA talks, though a deal may not be reached in principle in time for the upcoming Summit of Americas as had been touted. EUR/USD is extremely contained between 1.2660-90, USD/JPY has recoiled around the 107.00 axis and USD/CHF is trapped within 0.9590-0.96.

Core bonds are on the retreat again after a rebound on the China devaluation headlines soon fizzled out, with Bunds and Gilts now extending losses to 21 and 26 ticks respectively at the new 159.34 and 122.18 Eurex and Liffe intraday lows. EU stocks are hugging highs on less anxiety over the US-China trade tiff in general, although latest Chinese comments remain relatively resolute and come with the threat of Yuan devaluation, according to sources anyway. US Treasuries also on the retreat after initial post-US labour data gains last Friday and with the curve steeper ahead of this week’s auctions, FOMC minutes and CPI data. Back to the 10 year EU benchmarks, and technically Bund bears may now look at Friday’s low of 159.15, while nearest downside chart support comes in at 122.10, which is the April 5 session base.

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures trade modestly higher but in close proximity to some of the lows seen on Friday amid trade concerns and an uptick in the Baker Hughes rig count. Elsewhere, energy-specific newsflow has been relatively quiet over the weekend but traders will continue to be mindful of geopolitical developments with US President Trump warning Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and allies that they could pay a big price following a suspected chemical attack that killed dozens over the weekend. Furthermore, Iranian President Rouhani has stated that US President Trump will regret any withdrawal from the Iranian nuclear deal and that Iran’s response to the matter will be stronger than imagined. In metals markets, spot gold has fallen victim to the apparent return of risk appetite to the market and the modestly firmer USD. Elsewhere, Dalian iron ore slipped to a 10-month low in Asia-Pac trade amid ongoing trade concerns whilst aluminium has been seen higher during London hours amid the potential fallout of sanctions by the US on Russian aluminium producer Rusal.

subject: EU DEBT UPDATE: Bunds and Gilts in tight ranges below last Friday’s closes
content: Gradual slippage after the initial modest Eurex markdown, with the 10 year German debt future just trading down to 159.34 for a 16 tick loss on the day and making a bit more room for EU cash bourses to realise recovery gains indicated via equity futures. Further reflection on the latest US jobs report suggests no material change in the 2018 Fed rate path, while a raft of US officials have been clarifying the latest tariff proposals as the next stage in the bargaining strategy for trade talks with China rather than a fait accompli. Turning to Gilts, and catch-up losses off Monday’s Liffe open in line with counterpart core debt, unsurprisingly, with the 10 year UK benchmark down to 122.25 vs 122.44 at last Friday’s close before paring some losses alongside Bunds (just bounced to 159.46) to 122.40 amidst wire headlines suggesting that China may us Yuan devaluation as its next move in the spat with the US. At the short end of the curves, Euribor and Short Sterling contracts also on rhe defensive.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Telecom Italia, Novartis and Swiss Re
content:
9th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks initially began the week rangebound with a non-committal tone seen in the region following the stock rout last Friday on Wall St after President Trump upped the ante on possible trade tariffs against China and US NFP data fell short of estimates. However, sentiment then gradually improved throughout the trading day which was attributed to US efforts over the weekend to alleviate trade concerns in which President Trump predicted that the US would reach an agreement with China on trade and after White House economic adviser Kudlow explicitly stated that this is not a trade war. As such, ASX 200 (+0.4%) shrugged off the early indecision and traded positive, although weakness in mining and energy names capped upside, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was lifted by JPY weakness. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) recovered from the initial cobwebs seen on the mainland’s re-open from a 4-day closure and first opportunity to react to the additional USD 100bln tariff consideration against China, while Hang Seng (+1.9%) outperformed on declining money market rates after the PBoC resumed liquidity operations after halting for over 2 weeks.

FTSE

Barclays (BARC LN) - Co. is preparing to look for a successor to chairman John McFarlane. (Sky News)  

WPP (WPP LN) - Potential successors for besieged CEO Martin Sorrell have been identified in preparations for life after the longstanding CEO. (Times)

UK Retailers - UK retailers, including Debenhams (DEB LN), Marks & Spencer (MKS LN), WM Morrison (MRW LN) and Ocado (OCDO LN), are being targeted by short sellers, according to research by Linklaters. (Times) 

Smith & Nephew (SN/ LN) - New CEO Narwana is unlikely to pursue a radical change in strategy to his predecessor, according to sources. The sources added that his priorities are expected to include doing M&A and investing in innovation. (Telegraph)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Royal Mail (RMG LN) - CEO Greene is preparing to step down after 8 years. (Sky News)

De La Rue (DLAR LN) - Co. has hired lawyers Slaughter & May to help it fight the government's decision to let Gemalto (GTO NA) make new passports. (Telegraph) 

BROKER MOVES

ANGLO AMERICAN (AAL LN) DOWGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT SOCGEN

DAX

Adidas (ADS GY) – The sports co. is expecting to close stores in coming years as a focus on online sales is coming, with expectations of doubling e-commerce sales in the next two years. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The co. has named Christian Sewing as their new CEO, replacing John Cryan. (Newswires)

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) - Tata Steel is open to taking a majority stake in the tie up with the co, according to sources. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

US equity markets closed lower as trade concerns and soft nonfarm payrolls weighed on riskier assets. This miss on employment data, whilst seeing a small sell off in equities, was overawed by continued trade comments hammering stocks, with the Fed’s chair Powell saying trade wars are not a concern implying that rate increases will continue along the same path, putting further pressure on equities. This as well as comments from the White House seemingly shifting their focus from stock market prosperity to trade deficit reduction by accepting stock market volatility, saw equities close lower on the day.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks mostly higher as sentiment gradually improved throughout the session which was attributed to US efforts over the weekend to alleviate trade concerns
content:
• Asian stocks mostly higher as sentiment gradually improved throughout the session which was attributed to US efforts over the weekend to alleviate trade concerns

  • The major pairs were relatively rangebound overnight as currencies consolidated from the post-NFP price action
  • Looking ahead, highlights include potential comments from ECB’s Constancio and Praet

 

TRADE TARIFFS

US President Trump commented that he will always be friends with Chinese President Xi Jinping no matter what happens regarding the dispute on trade, while President Trump also noted that he predicts the US would prevail and reach agreements with China on trade issues. (Newswires)

White House economic advisor Kudlow said that he hopes the US will not use tariffs but added that it may have to, while he also stated that China’s first response was highly unsatisfactory. Furthermore, Kudlow commented that a tariff solution is possible in 3 months and that tariffs are not a bluff, while he further added that this is not a trade war. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US is willing to continue negotiations but that President Trump is prepared to defend US interests. Mnuchin also commented that there is a potential for a trade war and that progress is being made on NAFTA as well as North Korea. (Newswires)

US President Trump didn't seek advice from White House economic adviser Kudlow on China tariffs, while Chief of Staff Kelly was said to be blindsided by speed of tariff announcements. Furthermore, reports added that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Lighthizer worked in lockstep on the China tariffs. (Axios)

PBoC policy adviser said that China should invest more in real assets rather than invest in US debt and that US is seeking to restrict China's rise via trade war. However, there were also comments from China think-tank CASS that the nation is unlikely to use USTs as a trade war weapon. That said, this appears to be at odds with research from SGH Macro which suggests that their understanding is that China has halted purchases of USTs. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian stocks initially began the week rangebound with a non-committal tone seen in the region following the stock rout last Friday on Wall St after President Trump upped the ante on possible trade tariffs against China and US NFP data fell short of estimates. However, sentiment then gradually improved throughout the trading day which was attributed to US efforts over the weekend to alleviate trade concerns in which President Trump predicted that the US would reach an agreement with China on trade and after White House economic adviser Kudlow explicitly stated that this is not a trade war. As such, ASX 200 (+0.4%) shrugged off the early indecision and traded positive, although weakness in mining and energy names capped upside, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was lifted by JPY weakness. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) recovered from the initial cobwebs seen on the mainland’s re-open from a 4-day closure and first opportunity to react to the additional USD 100bln tariff consideration against China, while Hang Seng (+1.9%) outperformed on declining money market rates after the PBoC resumed liquidity operations after halting for over 2 weeks. Finally, 10-yr JGBs were uneventful with marginal gains seen as they tracked recent price action in T-notes and with the BoJ also in the market to the tune of JPY 710bln in the belly to super-long end.

PBoC injected CNY 10bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3114 (Prev. 6.2926)


UK/EU

In Italian politics, the 5SM are set to unveil their economic plan which will keep the budget deficit near the level forecasts by the outgoing centre-left government. Elsewhere, the nation’s three main right-leaning parties have announced that they will present a united front ahead of a fresh round of talks this week. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed France’s sovereign rating at AA; outlook stable. DBRS raised Spain's sovereign rating to A from A (low); stable trend. (Newswires)

Hungary PM Orban is projected to win a 3rd term after the ruling party was said to receive 49.5% of votes and is set to win two-thirds majority in Parliament. (Newswires)

FX

The major pairs were relatively rangebound overnight as currencies consolidated from the post-NFP price action in which the greenback weakened across the board due to the disappointing jobs numbers. Nonetheless, the DXY-index has nursed some losses amid a modest pullback in EUR/USD, while GBP/USD traded sideways and within proximity for another attempt to reclaim the 1.4100 handle to the upside. Elsewhere, AUD was initially restricted by a lacklustre commodity complex but then gained as the risk tone brightened, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses also recovered some of the lost ground from last week’s miss on US jobs data and safe-haven flows into JPY, in which the pair just about reclaimed the 107.00 handle.

Canadian PM Trudeau said he is hopeful to get promising news on NAFTA in the coming time, while Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said they have had good NAFTA conversations so far and that they are a in a new more intensive phase of discussions. Furthermore, there were also reports that a senior Mexican economy ministry official was said to be very convinced that a new NAFTA agreement on trade will be reached very soon and that the next round of NAFTA talks are planned for today in Washington DC. (Newswires)

Reports stated that no deal in principle regarding NAFTA is expected to be announced in the upcoming Summit of Americas in Lima, Peru. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mixed overnight in which WTI crude futures nursed some of the Friday’s losses where trade concerns and poor data contributed to the risk averse tone and dragged prices briefly below the USD 62/bbl. Elsewhere, gold was marginally lower amid a slight recovery in the greenback and improvement in risk tone, while copper remained lacklustre amid subdued metal prices in China where Dalian iron ore slipped to a 10-month low in early trade.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (29 Mar) 1003 (Prev. 993). (Newswires)
US Baker Hughes Oil Rig Count (29 Mar) 808 (Prev. 798)
US Baker Hughes Gas Rig Count (29 Mar) 194 (Prev. 194)

Norway private sector trade union reached a wage deal which averted strike action that would have involved at least 35,000 workers in aluminium, oil and chemical industries. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

Syrian state TV Sana confirmed reports of an air strike on a Syrian military airport in Homs and initially stated that the US was the source of the attack on Syria. However, the Pentagon denied that they had conducted a strike and Syria state media later identified Israel as the likely source of the military attack. (Newswires)

US President Trump warned Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his 2 largest allies could pay a big price following a suspected chemical attack killed dozens over the weekend, while he also noted that Russia and Iran are responsible for backing the Syrian President. (Newswires)

North Korea is reportedly prepared to discuss denuclearization, while reports added that Pyongyang has signalled progress towards denuclearization should move in phases in tandem with diplomatic and economic concessions from the US. (Newswires)

China banned exports of items to North Korea that could potentially be used in WMDs to comply with UN resolution, while reports added that had identified 32 items which it will ban. (Newswires)

Russia is to respond to US sanctions, according to reports in local press. (TASS)

 

US

US Treasuries closed higher as trade concerns and soft jobs data sent rates lower. Donald Trump’s threat to slap further tariffs on Chinese goods lifted treasuries before the CME open with the curve initially bull-steepening. The disappointing jobs data gave further impetus for bond bulls as the 10y yield dropped back below 2.8%. Fed Chairman Powell reiterated that further gradual rate hikes would be necessary, which saw market pricing for a June hike remain around 70%. However, odds of a fourth interest rate hike are still remarkably low as Powell said it was too early to say how tariffs and trade talk will affect the outlook. T-Note futures (June 2018) settled up 14+ ticks at 121-00+.

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said the US economy will require further gradual interest rate hikes and noted 12-month inflation readings should move up notably this spring. Powell also commented that inflation could rise to unwelcome levels if the Fed waited for inflation and employment to hit its goals, while he added that it is too early to say how tariffs and trade talk will affect outlook. (Newswires)

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawk) said 3 to 4 hikes this year is the right direction and that Fed needs to keep raising rates to avoid overheating. (Newswires)

Fed’s Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said that the US economy is very strong and that he is optimistic on inflation reaching 2% target. (Newswires)

US National Security Council spokesman Michael Anton announced to resign from role at the White House to take up a position in Hillsdale College's Kirby Center. (Politico)

Nonetheless, the DXY-index has nursed some losses amid a modest pullback in EUR/USD, while GBP/USD trades sideways and within proximity for another attempt to reclaim the 1.4100 handle to the upside. subject: Twitter sources report explosions being heard at Syria's T4 airbase and that aircrafts were reported to have crossed over Lebanon into Syria - Unconfirmed
analysis_details:
- As a reminder, US President Trump suggested that Syrian President al-Assad and allies had a price to pay after a chemical weapons attack in Syria over the weekend. Furthermore, sources noted chatter earlier that the White House was nearing a decision on whether to hit Syria following the chemical weapons attack. 
- Note: There has not yet been any confirmation regarding who is conducting the strikes on Syrian airbases.
